lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
Total variation distance. Confidence intervals for hypothesis testing. Permutation testing.

Comparing two samples. Comparing two samples.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: Recall: Jury panels in Alameda County
section:
We have two distributions:

The ethnic distribution of all eligible panelists in Alameda County ‚Äì this is a population distribution.
The ethnic distribution of 1453 observed panelists ‚Äì this is a sample distribution. The ethnic distribution of all eligible panelists in Alameda County ‚Äì this is a population distribution. lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: Are the differences in representation meaningful?
section: Null Hypothesis: Panelists were selected at random from the eligible population. Alternative Hypothesis: Panelists were not selected at random from the eligible population. Last class, we introduced a test statistic that quantifies how different two categorical distributions are.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
The Total Variation Distance (TVD) of two categorical distributions is the sum of the absolute differences of their proportions, all divided by 2. Input: def total_variation_distance(dist1, dist2):
    '''Computes the TVD between two categorical distributions, 
       assuming the categories appear in the same order.'''
    return np.abs((dist1 - dist2)).sum() / 2 Input: jury Ethnicity

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: Model: Panels are drawn at from the eligible population. Statistic: TVD between the random panel's ethnicity distribution and the eligible population's ethnicity distribution. Repeat many times to generate many TVDs, and see where the TVD of the observed panelists lies.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
Input: eligible = jury.get('Eligible')
sample_distribution = np.random.multinomial(1453, eligible) / 1453 
sample_distribution Output: array([0.14, 0.18, 0.13, 0.55, 0.01]) Input: total_variation_distance(sample_distribution, eligible) Output: 0.013778389538885053 Note: np.random.multinomial creates samples drawn with replacement, even though real jury panels would be drawn without replacement. However, when the sample size (1453) is small relative to the population (number of people in Alameda County), the resulting distributions will be roughly the same whether we sample with or without replacement.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
Input: tvds = np.array([])
repetitions = 10000
for i in np.arange(repetitions):
    sample_distribution = np.random.multinomial(1453, eligible) / 1453
    new_tvd = total_variation_distance(sample_distribution, eligible)
    tvds = np.append(tvds, new_tvd) Input: observed_tvd = total_variation_distance(jury.get('Panels'), eligible)

bpd.DataFrame().assign(tvds=tvds).plot(kind='hist', density=True, bins=20, ec='w', figsize=(10, 5),
                                      title='Empirical Distribution of TVD Between Eligible Population and Random Sample')
plt.axvline(observed_tvd, color='black', linewidth=4, label='Observed Statistic')
plt.legend();

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
Input: np.count_nonzero(tvds >= observed_tvd) / repetitions Output: 0.0 Random samples from the eligible population are typically much more similar to the eligible population than our observed data. We see this in the empirical distribution, which consists of small TVDs (much smaller than our observed TVD). Input: jury.assign(RandomSample=sample_distribution).plot(kind='barh', x='Ethnicity', figsize=(10, 5),
                                                   title = "A Random Sample is Usually Similar to the Eligible Population");

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
Likely not! The distributions of ethnicities in our random samples are not like the distribution of ethnicities in our observed panelists. This doesn't say why the distributions are different!

Juries are drawn from voter registration lists and DMV records. Certain populations are less likely to be registered to vote or have a driver's license due to historical biases.
The county rarely enacts penalties for those who don't appear for jury duty; certain populations are less likely to be able to miss work to appear for jury duty.
See the report for more reasons. Juries are drawn from voter registration lists and DMV records. Certain populations are less likely to be registered to vote or have a driver's license due to historical biases. The county rarely enacts penalties for those who don't appear for jury duty; certain populations are less likely to be able to miss work to appear for jury duty. See the report for more reasons.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
It turns out that we can use confidence intervals for hypothesis testing, when our hypotheses take a certain form:

Null Hypothesis: The population parameter is equal to some value, $x$.
Alternative Hypothesis: The population parameter is not equal to $x$. Null Hypothesis: The population parameter is equal to some value, $x$. Alternative Hypothesis: The population parameter is not equal to $x$. We'll use the following strategy.

Choose a p-value cutoff of p%.
Construct a (100-p)% confidence interval for the population parameter.
Interpret the results:
If $x$ is not in the confidence interval, we reject the null hypothesis.
If $x$ is in the confidence interval, we fail to reject the null hypothesis (since our results are consistent with the null). Choose a p-value cutoff of p%. Construct a (100-p)% confidence interval for the population parameter. Interpret the results: If $x$ is not in the confidence interval, we reject the null hypothesis. If $x$ is in the confidence interval, we fail to reject the null hypothesis (since our results are consistent with the null).

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
We will test the following hypotheses at the standard p = 0.05 significance level.

Null Hypothesis: The mean body temperature of all people is 98.6 ¬∫F.
Alternative Hypothesis: The mean body temperature of all people is not 98.6 ¬∫F. Null Hypothesis: The mean body temperature of all people is 98.6 ¬∫F. Alternative Hypothesis: The mean body temperature of all people is not 98.6 ¬∫F. The mean body temperature of all people is a population parameter. We can estimate this parameter with a confidence interval. Since we are estimating a population mean, there are two possible approaches to creating a confidence interval.

Bootstrapping.
Using the Central Limit Theorem. Bootstrapping. Using the Central Limit Theorem.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: Bootstrap-based confidence interval for mean body temperature
section:
We are given a sample of 130 body temperatures.  We can bootstrap this original sample to calculate many resample means, then use percentiles to find a 95% confidence interval for the population mean. Input: resample_means = np.array([])
for i in np.arange(10000):
    resample = temperatures.sample(130, replace=True)
    resample_means = np.append(resample_means, resample.get('temperature').mean())
resample_means Output: array([98.28, 98.28, 98.27, ..., 98.33, 98.18, 98.35]) Input: left_boot = np.percentile(resample_means, 2.5)
right_boot = np.percentile(resample_means, 97.5)

# 95% bootstrap-based confidence interval for the mean body temperature of all people:
[left_boot, right_boot] Output: [98.12230769230769, 98.37307692307692]

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: CLT-based confidence interval for mean body temperature
section:
We can alternatively use the CLT to calculate a 95% confidence interval for the population mean: Thanks to the CLT, we have an understanding of the distribution of the sample mean, even though we don't know anything about the distribution of body temperatures. We don't need to assume that body temperatures are normally distributed to use the CLT! Input: sample_mean_mean = temperatures.get('temperature').mean()
sample_mean_mean Output: 98.24923076923078 Input: sample_mean_sd = np.std(temperatures.get('temperature')) / np.sqrt(temperatures.shape[0])
sample_mean_sd Output: 0.06405661469519337 Input: left_normal = sample_mean_mean - 2 * sample_mean_sd
right_normal = sample_mean_mean + 2 * sample_mean_sd

# 95% CLT-based confidence interval for the mean body temperature of all people:
[left_normal, right_normal] Output: [98.12111753984038, 98.37734399862117]

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: Comparing intervals and interpreting the results

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
98.6 ¬∫F is due to Carl Reinhold August Wunderlich, a 19th century physician, who conducted a study when thermometers were new.

This LA Times article states that it's likely that Wunderlich's thermometer was miscalibrated. This LA Times article states that it's likely that Wunderlich's thermometer was miscalibrated. A recent article by the Yale School of Medicine states that the average body temperature has declined  over the last 150 years by 1.5 ¬∫F, and that body temperature depends on the time of day, age, and sex, among other things.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: So far, we've used hypothesis tests to answer questions of the form: I have a population distribution, and I have one sample. Does this sample look like it was drawn from the population? Next, we want to consider questions of the form: I have two samples, but no information about any population distributions. Do these samples look like they were drawn from the same population? We can't use hypothesis testing to answer such questions yet, because all of our hypothesis tests have relied on knowing the population distribution. But what if you don't know the population distribution? Are the distributions of weight for babies üë∂ born to smoking mothers vs. non-smoking mothers different? Are the distributions of pressure drops for footballs üèà from two different teams different? These questions are answered through A/B testing. Permutation testing is one type of A/B testing.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: In 2008, the Obama campaign tested several different versions of a pop-up box on their website. Each visitor to the site would view a random version of the site, with different buttons and images. For each version, they recorded the number of people who signed up to be a donor. Read more at this blog post.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: Here are the four different buttons they used. Which one do you think would lead to the most signups?

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: It is estimated that this combination of image and button brought in an additional 60 million dollars in donations versus the original version of the site.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
Question: Is there a significant difference in the weights of babies born to mothers who smoked vs. babies born to mothers who didn't smoke? To approach this question, we'll look at data from a research study.

Each row corresponds to a baby.
There are two groups of babies: those whose mothers smoked ("smokers' babies"), and those whose mothers didn't smoke ("non-smokers' babies"). Each row corresponds to a baby. There are two groups of babies: those whose mothers smoked ("smokers' babies"), and those whose mothers didn't smoke ("non-smokers' babies"). lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: Visualizing the distribution of each group
section:
Input: smokers = babies[babies.get('Maternal Smoker')]
non_smokers = babies[babies.get('Maternal Smoker') == False] Input: fig, ax = plt.subplots()
baby_bins = np.arange(50, 200, 5)
non_smokers.plot(kind='hist', density=True, ax=ax, alpha=0.75, bins=baby_bins, ec='w', figsize=(10, 5))
smokers.plot(kind='hist', density=True, ax=ax, alpha=0.75, bins=baby_bins, ec='w')
plt.legend(['Maternal Smoker = False', 'Maternal Smoker = True'])
plt.xlabel('Birth Weight'); What do you notice? üëÄ

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: It appears that, in our sample, smokers' babies typically have lower birth weights than non-smokers' babies. Does the difference we see reflect a real difference in the population? Or is this pattern just due to random chance? Let's run a hypothesis test!

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: Null Hypothesis: In the population, birth weights of smokers' babies and non-smokers' babies have the same distribution, and the observed differences in our samples are due to random chance. Alternative Hypothesis: In the population, smokers' babies have lower birth weights than non-smokers' babies, on average. The observed differences in our samples cannot be explained by random chance alone. Now that we have our hypotheses, we need to devise a test statistic that we can simulate under the null hypothesis.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: We recently introduced the total variation distance (TVD) as a test statistic. Why can't we use the TVD as our test statistic in this hypothesis test?

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: Test statistic: the difference in group means
section:
The test statistic we'll use is the difference in group means: Note that large values of this test statistic favor the alternative hypothesis. Let's compute the observed statistic: Input: means_df = babies.groupby('Maternal Smoker').mean()
means_df Birth Weight


Maternal Smoker



False
123.09


True
113.82 Birth Weight  Birth Weight Maternal Smoker Maternal Smoker  False
123.09 False 123.09 True
113.82 True 113.82 Input: # The difference between the mean birth weight for non-smokers and smokers.
means = means_df.get('Birth Weight')
observed_difference = means.loc[False] - means.loc[True]
observed_difference Output: 9.266142572024918

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: Null Hypothesis: In the population, birth weights of smokers' babies and non-smokers' babies have the same distribution, and the observed differences in our samples are due to random chance. Alternative Hypothesis: In the population, smokers' babies have lower birth weights than non-smokers' babies, on average. The observed differences in our samples cannot be explained by random chance alone. Test statistic: Difference in mean birth weight of non-smokers' babies and smokers' babies.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section_name: Generating new samples under the null hypothesis
section: Under the null hypothesis, both groups are sampled from the same population distribution. We need to sample from that population distribution to create an empirical distribution of test statistics under the assumptions of the null hypothesis. üö® Issue: We don't have the population distribution, so we can't draw samples from it!

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: Idea: We can construct a "population" by combining both of our samples. Then, to create two random samples from it, we just separate (or split) the population into two random groups. We can do this because, under the null hypothesis, the mother's smoking status has no impact on the baby's birth weight, so all baby weights come from the same population. Input: show_permutation_testing_intro()

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section:
The total variation distance is a test statistic that measures the difference between two categorical distributions.

Note: the TVD is not used for permutation tests! Note: the TVD is not used for permutation tests! Before today, we used hypothesis tests to determine if one sample came from a known population distribution. Permutation tests help us determine if two samples came from the same population. We can answers questions like:

"Do smokers' babies and non-smokers babies' weigh the same?"
More generally: are these things like those things? "Do smokers' babies and non-smokers babies' weigh the same?" More generally: are these things like those things?

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: Permutation tests are one way to perform A/B tests. These are both also hypothesis tests. An A/B test aims to determine if two samples are from the same population (the name comes from giving names to the samples ‚Äì sample A and sample B). We implemented A/B tests by using permutations. Butside of this class, permutation tests can be used for other purposes, and A/B tests can be done without permutations. For us, they mean the same thing, so if you see A/B test anywhere in the class, it refers to a permutation test.

lecture_title: TVD, Hypothesis Testing, and Permutation Testing
section: Two full examples of permutation tests.
